review.title: Efficient Induction of Finite State Automata
review.abstract: this 1990 paper introduces a remarkable new algorithm for satisfying the induction if complex randomly finite state nonlinear automata originates from samples definitions of behavior. the extended algorithm is based on information theoretic principles. extending the algorithm reduces substantially the search parameter space by many orders of magnitude over what each was seemingly previously traditionally thought possible. we compare applying the algorithm with upgrading some previously existing induction reinforcement techniques for finite state additive automata and show today that the verification algorithm themselves is much superior in testing both complexity run time and quality of inductions.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Thirteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1997)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Thirteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1997)

The methods that the IGS algorithm is compared with are the k-tails of algorithm Biermann and Feldman (1972) and the sk-strings algorithm of Raman and Patrick (1995).

The methods that the IGS algorithm is compared with are the k-tails of algorithm Biermann and Feldman (1972) and the sk-strings algorithm of Raman and Patrick (1995). The sk-strings algorithm of Raman and Patrick (1995) is assumed to be the current state of the art for the induction style of merging states based on equivalence relations.

The sk-strings algorithm of Raman and Patrick (1995) is assumed to be the current state of the art for the induction style of merging states based on equivalence relations.

metadata.abstractText: This paper introduces a new algorithm for the induction of complex finite state automata from samples of behaviour. The algorithm is based on information theoretic principles. The algorithm reduces the search space by many orders of magnitude over what was previously thought possible. We compare the algorithm with some existing induction techniques for finite state automata and show that the algorithm is much superior in both run time and quality of inductions.
